questions.text: Most radiosensitive phase of cell is:
Nowadays radium is not used in the treatment of cancer because:

options.label: A
options.text: It decays faster and needs frequent replacement

options.label: B
options.text: It decays into daughter Radon which is a constant hazard

options.label: C
options.text: It has a very long half life

options.label: D
options.text: It is a very unstable element

questions.correct_answer: B. It decays into daughter Radon which is a constant hazard
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) It decays faster and needs frequent replacement (Incorrect) Radium-226 has a very long half-life of 1,600 years, meaning it does not decay quickly. Frequent replacement would not be a significant concern.
  • • (C) It has a very long half-life (Incorrect) While it is true that radium-226 has a long half-life, this alone is not the reason it is no longer used. The primary concern is the hazardous decay product (radon gas), not the longevity of radium itself.
  • • (D) It is a very unstable element (Incorrect) Radium is radioactive, but it is not considered "very unstable" compared to other isotopes used in radiotherapy. Its instability is not the primary reason for its discontinuation in medical treatments.

questions.text: Radiation is not used in:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) CAT Scan Computed Axial Tomography (CAT or CT scan) uses X-ray radiation to create detailed cross-sectional images of the body. Since it relies on ionizing radiation, it is not the correct answer.
  • • (C) Digital Subtraction Imaging Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) is an imaging technique used in vascular studies. It involves the use of X-ray radiation with contrast agents to visualize blood vessels clearly, making radiation essential for this procedure.
  • • (D) Thyroid Scan A thyroid scan is a nuclear medicine test that uses radioactive isotopes (like iodine-123 or technetium-99m) to assess thyroid function and detect abnormalities such as nodules or cancer. Since radiation is involved, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Radiation mediates its effect by:
The element used for intracavitary RT in carcinoma cervix:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (B) Cobalt-60 Cobalt-60 is not used for intracavitary brachytherapy but is commonly employed in external beam radiotherapy (EBRT). It emits high-energy gamma rays and is used in teletherapy units for deep-seated tumors, including cervical cancer, but not for intracavitary placement.
  • • (C) Strontium Strontium-90 is used in superficial radiation treatments, mainly for ophthalmic tumors (e.g., pterygium, retinoblastoma) and skin cancers. It does not penetrate deeply enough for intracavitary treatment of cervical cancer.
  • • (D) Radio Iodine Radioactive iodine (I-131) is primarily used in thyroid cancer treatment and hyperthyroidism. It works by being selectively taken up by thyroid tissue, leading to targeted destruction. It has no role in intracavitary radiotherapy for cervical cancer.

questions.text: Least affected by radiation:
Which of the following respond best to radiotherapy?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • B. Teratoma: Teratomas are radioresistant and do not respond well to radiotherapy. They are composed of differentiated tissues from multiple germ layers, making them less susceptible to radiation-induced damage. Instead, treatment involves surgical excision, and in some cases, chemotherapy for metastatic disease.
  • • C. Choriocarcinoma: Choriocarcinoma is highly resistant to radiotherapy but responds very well to chemotherapy, particularly platinum-based regimens (e.g., BEP – Bleomycin, Etoposide, Cisplatin). It is a highly aggressive tumor with early hematogenous spread, making systemic therapy more appropriate.
  • • D. Endometrial carcinoma: While radiotherapy is used in the adjuvant setting or for palliation, endometrial carcinoma is not the most radiosensitive tumor. Instead, its treatment often involves surgery (hysterectomy) followed by radiation or chemotherapy in advanced cases. It does not respond as dramatically to radiotherapy as seminoma.

questions.text: Mantle irradiation is used in:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Leukaemia: Radiotherapy is not the primary treatment for leukemia because it is a systemic blood cancer rather than a localized tumor. Whole-body irradiation may be used in bone marrow transplantation protocols, but mantle irradiation is not a standard approach for leukemia.
  • • C. Chest secondaries from some cancers: While radiotherapy can be used for palliative treatment of metastatic tumors in the chest (e.g., lung metastases), mantle irradiation is not the preferred approach. Instead, targeted radiation or systemic therapies are typically used.
  • • D. Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is primarily treated with chemotherapy, surgery, and targeted radiotherapy for localized tumors. Mantle irradiation is not used because neuroblastomas arise from adrenal or sympathetic nervous system tissue, not the lymphatic system.

questions.text: One gray of radiation is equal to:
One of the following radioisotopes is used for interstitial therapy:
Cell most sensitive to radiation:
Radioactivity was discovered by:
Radiosensitising substances include:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Oxygen: One of the most potent natural radiosensitizers. The oxygen effect increases radiation damage by stabilizing free radicals produced by ionizing radiation, making DNA damage more lethal. Hypoxic (low-oxygen) tumor cells are more resistant to radiation, while well-oxygenated cells are more sensitive.
  • • B. SR 2508: A nitroimidazole compound that acts as a hypoxic cell radiosensitizer. It mimics the effect of oxygen and enhances radiation damage in hypoxic tumor cells, which are otherwise more resistant to radiotherapy.
  • • C. Metronidazole: A nitroimidazole drug that can also act as a radiosensitizer under hypoxic conditions. It enhances the effects of radiation on low-oxygen tumor cells, making treatment more effective.
  • • D. Misonidazole: Another hypoxic cell radiosensitizer belonging to the nitroimidazole group. It works similarly to SR 2508 and Metronidazole, sensitizing hypoxic cells to radiation damage.

questions.text: Substance(s) which offer preferential radioprotection to tissues is/are:
questions.correct_answer: D. A and B are correct
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Cysteine: Correct. Cysteine is an amino acid with a sulfhydryl (-SH) group, which acts as a free radical scavenger. It helps protect normal tissues from radiation-induced damage by reducing oxidative stress and stabilizing cellular components.
  • • B. Thiophosphate YVR 2721 (Amifostine): Correct. Amifostine (WR-2721) is a well-known radioprotector that preferentially protects normal tissues from radiation damage while allowing radiation to target cancer cells. It works by scavenging free radicals and increasing DNA repair in healthy cells.
  • • C. Metronidazole: Incorrect. Metronidazole is a radiosensitizer, not a radioprotector. It enhances radiation effects, particularly in hypoxic tumor cells, making them more sensitive to radiation therapy rather than protecting normal tissues.

questions.text: Commonly used type of radiation in radiotherapy is:
Low dose radiotherapy is given for:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • B. Malignant melanoma: Incorrect. Melanoma is highly radioresistant, meaning it does not respond well to conventional radiotherapy. Instead, treatment primarily involves surgery and immunotherapy (e.g., checkpoint inhibitors like nivolumab or pembrolizumab).
  • • C. Osteosarcoma: Incorrect. Osteosarcoma is also radioresistant, meaning radiotherapy has a limited role in its management. Instead, treatment mainly consists of surgery (limb-sparing or amputation) and chemotherapy (e.g., methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin).
  • • D. Chondrosarcoma: Incorrect. Chondrosarcoma is another radioresistant tumor. Surgical resection is the primary treatment, as radiotherapy is generally ineffective

questions.text: Point B in treatment of Ca cervix by radiotherapy corresponds to:
Latest source of neutrons for radio­therapy is:
In a modern rotatory anode X-ray tube cooling of anode is done by:
"Grid" is a device which is used for:

options.label: C
options.text: Reducing the contrast of the X-ray

questions.text: The following tumours of skin are radiosensitive, except:
Out of the following which is not a radiotherapy equipment?
Radioactive gold is used in:
Radioactive phosphorous is used in treatment of:
Most radio-dense substance is:
Acute radiation sickness is characterised by:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Hematological Symptoms Radiation damages bone marrow, leading to pancytopenia (low RBCs, WBCs, and platelets). Symptoms include infection (due to low WBCs), bleeding (low platelets), and anemia (low RBCs). This occurs at doses of 1–2 Gy (Gray units) and is known as the hematopoietic syndrome.
  • • B. CNS Symptoms At very high doses (>30 Gy), radiation causes direct damage to neurons and cerebral edema. Symptoms include seizures, loss of consciousness, ataxia, and cardiovascular collapse. This is known as the neurovascular syndrome, which is rapidly fatal.
  • • C. Gastrointestinal Symptoms Radiation destroys the intestinal lining, leading to severe nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and dehydration. This occurs at doses of 6–10 Gy and is part of the gastrointestinal syndrome. Death can occur due to sepsis, dehydration, and malabsorption.

questions.text: The tissue most resistant to radioactivity is:
Intracavitary radiation is given in:
Most radiosensitive of the following is:
The principle used in radiotherapy is:
The most common presentation of radia­tion carditis is:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • B. Atheromatous plaques Radiation accelerates coronary artery disease (CAD) by causing endothelial damage, leading to fibrosis, intimal thickening, and premature atherosclerosis. However, pericardial effusion is a more common initial manifestation than atherosclerotic plaques.
  • • C. Myocardial fibrosis Radiation can cause myocardial fibrosis, leading to cardiomyopathy, conduction defects, and heart failure. However, myocardial fibrosis typically occurs later after significant radiation exposure, whereas pericardial effusion is an earlier and more common presentation.
  • • D. Pyogenic pericarditis Pyogenic (infectious) pericarditis is not a typical consequence of radiation exposure. Radiation-induced pericarditis is usually sterile (non-infectious) and results from inflammatory and fibrotic changes.

questions.text: Most common skin manifestation of radiotherapy:
The most sensitive cell cycle stage for radiotherapy is:
All of the following are used in interstitial brachytherapy except:
Increased radioisotopes are seen in all of the following except
Which of the following is most radio­sensitive tumour?
Which of the following is most radioresistant?
Which of the following is the most radiosensitive ovarian tumour?
Which of the following radioisotopes is commonly used as a source for external beam radiotherapy in the treatment of cancer patients?
What dose of radiation therapy is recommended for pain relief in bone metastases?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • B. 20 Gy in 5 fractions → Effective but requires more sessions This fractionation schedule (4 Gy × 5 fractions) is also commonly used for bone metastases. It provides similar pain relief to the 8 Gy single dose but requires more hospital visits. It is preferred for patients with better prognosis who may benefit from a more prolonged pain control.
  • • C. 30 Gy in 10 fractions → Used for long-term control This regimen (3 Gy × 10 fractions) is used in patients with a longer expected survival and those with spinal cord compression or pathological fractures. However, for pure pain relief, shorter regimens like 8 Gy single fraction or 20 Gy in 5 fractions are preferred.
  • • D. Above 70 Gy → Not used for palliative bone metastases Such high doses are typically used in curative radiotherapy (e.g., head and neck, prostate, or cervical cancers). Bone metastases are not treated with curative intent, so such high doses are not appropriate

questions.text: After contrast media infection in the Radiology department, a patient develops severe hypotension, bronchospasm and cyanosis. Which one of the following drugs should be used for treatment?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Atropine → Used for bradycardia, not anaphylaxis
  • • Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist used for bradycardia and organophosphate poisoning.
  • • It does not reverse hypotension, bronchospasm, or anaphylaxis.
  • • B. Aminophylline → Used for asthma, not first-line for anaphylaxis
  • • Aminophylline is a bronchodilator (xanthine derivative) used in asthma and COPD.
  • • It is not effective in reversing anaphylactic shock and does not treat hypotension.
  • • C. Dopamine → Used for hypotension but not first-line
  • • Dopamine is a vasopressor used in shock, but it does not relieve bronchospasm.
  • • Adrenaline is preferred in anaphylaxis because it acts on both the heart (β1) and airways (β2)

questions.text: The most radiosensitive tumor among the following is:
All of the following modalities can be used for in situ ablation of liver secondaries, except:
All of the following radioisotopes are used as systemic radionuclide, except:
Phosphorous-32 emits:
Which of the following is used in the treatment of differentiated thyroid cancer
Which of the following malignant tumours is radioresistant?
Which one of the following radioisotope is not used as permanent implant?
The technique employed in radiotherapy to counteract the effect of tumour motion due to breathing is known as:
At t = 0 there are 6 x 10 23 radioactive atoms of a substance, which decay with a disintegration constant (A.) equal to 0.01/ sec. What would be the initial decay rate?
Which of the following is the most radiosensitive tumour?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Ewing’s sarcoma is a radiosensitive bone tumor, and radiotherapy is often part of treatment.
  • • However, it is less sensitive than Hodgkin’s disease and usually requires multimodal therapy (chemo + RT + surgery).
  • • C. Carcinoma Cervix → Moderately radiosensitive
  • • Cervical cancer responds well to radiation therapy, especially squamous cell carcinoma.
  • • However, it is less radiosensitive compared to Hodgkin’s lymphoma.
  • • D. Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma (MFH) → Radioresistant
  • • MFH (Undifferentiated Pleomorphic Sarcoma) is typically radioresistant.
  • • Surgical resection is the primary treatment, with radiotherapy used for local control in certain cases.

questions.text: For which malignancy, intensity modulated radiotherapy (IMRT) is the most suitable?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Lung Cancer → Not the most suitable
  • • IMRT is used in lung cancer, but tumor motion due to breathing (respiratory motion) can limit its effectiveness.
  • • Techniques like stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) or 3D conformal radiotherapy are often preferred.
  • • C. Leukemias → Not treated with IMRT
  • • Leukemias are systemic malignancies, meaning they affect the blood and bone marrow rather than a localized tumor.
  • • Treatment mainly involves chemotherapy rather than localized radiotherapy.
  • • Total Body Irradiation (TBI) is used in some cases (e.g., before bone marrow transplantation), but IMRT is not the standard choice.
  • • D. Stomach Cancer → Not a primary indication
  • • Stomach cancer (gastric cancer) is usually treated with surgery and chemotherapy.
  • • Radiotherapy can be used postoperatively (adjuvant therapy), but IMRT is not the first-line choice.
  • • 3D conformal radiotherapy (3D-CRT) is often preferred for stomach cancer.

questions.text: In treatment of papillary carcinoma thyroid, radioiodine destroys the neoplastic cells predominantly by:
Planned radiation volume is:
questions.correct_answer: C. More than targeted radiation volume

questions.text: Conformation radiotherapy uses:
Radioactive element not used now-a­ days in medical practice:

What is the maximum radiation dose to point A for early and advanced Ca cervix?
Remote after loading technique useful for:
Tc 99labelled white cells used for:
questions.correct_answer: C. Terminal ileitis in Crohn's disease

questions.text: In water soluble radiological contrast, iodine : particle ratio is highest in:
